title: Extended Madd
desc1_desc: Extended Madd occurs when a letter with a madd sign (~) is followed by specific conditions, requiring the elongation of the sound. This can include meeting Hamzah (ء), Sukoon, or Shaddah, extending the sound for a specific number of beats.
desc2_desc: The duration of elongation depends on the type of Madd encountered. Below are the scenarios where the very long Madd applies:

Lessons.name: Prolonged Sign Meets Hamzah (ء) in the Next Word
Lessons.pengertian: When the madd letter is followed by Hamzah (ء) in the next word, the sound must be elongated for 2, 4, or 5 beats.
Lessons.caraMembaca: The reader stretches the sound based on context, ensuring a proper rhythm in recitation.

Lessons.name: Prolonged Sign Meets Hamzah (ء) in the Same Word
Lessons.pengertian: If the madd letter is followed by Hamzah (ء) in the same word, the elongation extends for 4 or 5 beats.
Lessons.caraMembaca: The reader ensures a clear elongation, respecting the rules of Tajweed.

Lessons.name: Prolonged Sign Meets Sukoon
Lessons.pengertian: If a madd letter meets Sukoon, the sound must be extended for 6 beats.
Lessons.caraMembaca: The reader carefully observes the Sukoon for precise elongation.

Lessons.name: Prolonged Sign Meets Shaddah
Lessons.pengertian: When the madd letter meets Shaddah, the extension is 6 beats.
Lessons.caraMembaca: The reader emphasizes the Shaddah while maintaining a steady rhythm.

tips.title: Mastering the Very Long Madd
tips.advice: To avoid errors or interruptions during elongation, one can follow the guidance of the Prophet (peace be upon him), as narrated by Al Baroo': 'Beautify the Quran with your voice.'

muqattaat.title: MuqaTTa'at (مُقَطَّعَات) Words
muqattaat.pengertian: Certain chapters of the Quran begin with disconnected letters known as Huroof al MuqaTTa'at. These letters must be stretched with the very-long Madd for 6 beats.
